lenders.name: Anthony
lenders.loan_because: “If among you, one of your brothers should become poor, in any of your towns within your land that the Lord your God is giving you, you shall not harden your heart or shut your hand against your poor brother, but you shall open your hand to him and lend him sufficient for his need, whatever it may be. Take care lest there be an unworthy thought in your heart and you say, ‘The seventh year, the year of release is near,’ and your eye look grudgingly on your poor brother, and you give him nothing, and he cry to the Lord against you, and you be guilty of sin. You shall give to him freely, and your heart shall not be grudging when you give to him, because for this the Lord your God will bless you in all your work and in all that you undertake. For there will never cease to be poor in the land. Therefore I command you, ‘You shall open wide your hand to your brother, to the needy and to the poor, in your land.’" (Deuteronomy 15:7-11)

I'm also passionate about the arts and blog and participate in a non-profit arts organisation which assists emerging artists and small ticket events in Sydney, Australia.

lenders.name: Far East Industry
lenders.loan_because: I googled all available bad publicity about KIVA, and realized that the cliche downsides of a charity organization generally speaking do not apply to KIVA. One case of a corrupt MFI was reported by KIVA itself which is refreshingly honest in my opinion. We live in an imperfect world; as long as a proper mechanism is in place to limit or even prevent corruption in the (money)-supply chain, such organization has my vote. For now I will attribute a small percentage of my company's funds for charity to KIVA, until I can see tangible (micro) results.

lenders.loan_because: My family has Lutherans, Roman Catholics, Christians of many types, and some who find spirituality in the good, green Earth.  We decided to invest in the world, rather than deal with the rat race of consumerism and materialism.  This Kiva site is our gift to one another.
lenders.occupational_info: We are teachers, engineers, doctors, nurses, businessmen, salesmen, carpenters, fishermen, and mothers and fathers.

lenders.name: Darren & Tammy
lenders.loan_because:
We are leaving Kiva due to their shift away from their stated mission and values, which were what attracted us to Kiva in the first place.  We are disappointed with Kiva's shift in values to include First World borrowers.  We feel strongly that the situation for so many Americans is truly lamentable, and it is shameful that US leaders have allowed financial, healthcare, education and housing problems to get so far out of control, but these are all problems we Americans can (and should) fix for ourselves, and we cannot ask entrepreneurs in the world's poorest regions to compete with US borrowers for funding.  

We actively support US programs to help America's poor and the families of her fallen heroes, and we agree that the US should start by taking care of its own poor, but we disagree that it is Kiva lenders' place to fill the gap.

We will not lend through Kiva until the organization returns to its original values and stated mission of alleviating world poverty by providing microlending resources to the world's most impoverished areas.  If Kiva makes the necessary course correction to return to its core values by limiting its borrowers to Third World entrepreneurs without access to traditional banking resources, we will happily return.

lenders.occupational_info: I work in a lab, finding new ways to fight difficult forms of cancer that don't respond to drugs or can't be operated on. My particular area of research is in Gene Therapy, which aims to undermine or cure cancer by instructing the body to fight it more efficiently, or by tricking the tumour into killing itself quietly and safely.

lenders.name: Tara
lenders.loan_because: I can.
lenders.occupational_info: I study the migration and movements of endangered North Atlantic right whales, and work to make predictions about where the whales will be throughout the year. There are certain human activities that can harm the whales - for instance, ships can collide with the whales and injure or kill them. Knowing where the whales are most likely to be allows us to make changes to ships' routes that can reduce the number of whale-ship collisions. For instance, in the past a fellow researcher asked captains of shipping vessels to make minor route changes that would take their ships around the areas with the most whales. Almost all captains agreed to the route changes, and this simple action is estimated to have saved a significant number of whales from injury and death.
